chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Complications
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Possible complications following a myocardial infarction (MI) include:
    • Acute heart failure:
      • Within hours after the MI — due to 'stunning' of the myocardium, an arrhythmia, or by an extensive volume of infarction.
      • In the days following the MI — due to rupture of a papillary muscle and resulting valvular incompetence, or by ventricular rupture resulting in a ventricular septal defect.
      • Anytime later — caused by acute decompensation of chronic heart failure, and in those with left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
    • Chronic heart failure — most commonly presents with breathlessness, fatigue, and oedema. For more information on the diagnosis and management of chronic heart failure, see the CKS topic on Heart failure - chronic.
    • Post-infarction angina — characterized by pain or heaviness in the centre of the chest triggered by effort or emotion. For information on the diagnosis and management of angina, see the CKS topic on Angina.
    • Stroke — People with coronary heart disease, or who have had an MI, are twice as likely to experience a stroke as people without these risk factors. For information on the diagnosis and management of stroke, see the CKS topic on Stroke and TIA.
    • Depression — up to 20% of people have a major depressive episode following an MI and a further 25% experience minor depression or depressed mood [Jiang et al, 2005]. For information on the diagnosis and management of depression, see the CKS topic on Depression.
    • Anxiety disorders — are thought to be common post-MI and may contribute to poorer outcomes [Roest et al, 2010]. One study found that 7% of people undergoing cardiac rehabilitation had an anxiety disorder [Bunevicius et al, 2013]. For information on the diagnosis and management of anxiety, see the CKS topic on Generalized anxiety disorder.
    • Dressler's syndrome — a pericarditis that occurs in about 4% of people post-MI. People typically present 2–4 weeks after an MI with a self-limiting febrile illness accompanied by pericardial or pleural pain [Gibson, 2003].
    • Sudden death — can occur shortly after MI because of myocardial rupture or fatal arrhythmia, or may occur at any time because of re-infarction or arrhythmia.

[Steg et al, 2012; Timmis, 2015; BHF, 2018; BMJ Best Practice, 2018]

• The prognosis following a myocardial infarction (MI) has considerably improved in recent years. This is largely attributable to modern treatments, in particular percutaneous coronary interventions and secondary preventative measures. For example:
    • The British Heart Foundation states that in the 1960s more than 70% of heart attacks in the UK were fatal, whereas today, at least 7 out of 10 people survive [BHF, 2018].
    • A Swedish study followed up 61,238 people with a first ST-elevation MI (STEMI) between 1996 and 2007, over which time the use of modern treatments greatly increased. In-hospital, 30-day and 1-year mortality rates decreased from 12.5% to 7.2%; from 15.0% to 8.6%; and from 21.0% to 13.3% respectively [Jernberg et al, 2011].
    • In England and Wales, the Myocardial Ischaemia National Audit Project (MINAP) reported that the 30-day mortality was almost 13% for STEMI in 2003–4, falling to 8% in 2011–12, with similar falls for NSTEMI [NICOR, 2013].
  • Greater degrees of myocardial necrosis are associated with a worse prognosis and higher risk of heart failure [Fox et al, 2004].
  • Other factors that may adversely affect prognosis following an MI include:
    • Comorbidities such as hypertension, chronic kidney disease, anaemia, and diabetes [Shu et al, 2006; Stebbins et al, 2010].
    • Site of the infarction. For example, a STEMI in the anterior part of heart has a less favourable prognosis than one in the inferior part of the heart [Stebbins et al, 2010].
    • Depression, particularly treatment-resistant and insufficiently treated depression [Licthman et al, 2014].
    • Older age and female sex [Stebbins et al, 2010; Canto et al, 2012].
